Title:
Clitolyophyllum wutaishanense, a new fan-shaped clitocyboid
agaric from temperate China
Keywords:
Lyophyllaceae, Basidiomycota, phylogeny, taxonomy, new
species
Abstract:
A novel, clitocyboid fungus from China is described as a
new species, Clitolyophyllum wutaishanense (Basidiomycota:
Lyophyllaceae). Phylogenetic analyses were based on sequences of the
nuclear ribosomal DNA internal transcribed spacer (nrITS) and large
subunit (nrLSU), and RNA polymerase II second largest subunit (RPB2)
regions. Our multigene phylogeny strongly supports the new taxon in
Clitolyophyllum as a sister species to Clitolyophyllum akcaabatense, a
species only known from Turkey. Fruiting bodies were found fruiting on
the ground in a forest of Larix gmelinii var. principis-rupprechtii and
are clitocyboid, becoming flabellate, pinkish white to greyish red, with
pale grey flesh and ellipsoid, hyaline, non-dextrinoid and non-amyloid
basidiospores. Basidiospores of Clitolyophyllum wutaishanense are
slightly longer and wider (7.69.9  4.15.4 m, averaging 8.5  4.7 m,
with average length/width ratio of 1.8) than those of Clitolyophyllum
akcaabatense (6.08.0 × 3.55 m), but with similar shape. In addition,
these two species can be distinguished by their nrITS, nrLSU and RPB2
sequences.
